channel.description:
Is it?
Discuss.
I think it is, atleast what I have read almost everyone says that it's 1, and here are some proofs:
Fraction proof:
0.333... = 1/3
3 x 0.333... = 3 x 1/3 = (3 x 1) / 3
0.999... = 1
And here is the Algebraic proof:
a = 0.999...
10a = 9.999...
10a - a = 9.999... - 0.999...
9c = 9
c = 1
So what do you think? What theories do you have? Post 'em here!

item.dc:creator: @Itachi_Uchiha Itachi Uchiha
item.description:
@Itachi_Uchiha wrote:

[quote=“Secet, post:1, topic:65609”]Fraction proof:

0.333… = 1/3

3 x 0.333… = 3 x 1/3 = (3 x 1) / 3

0.999… = 1[/quote]
.333… = 1/3
.666… = 2/3
.999… = 3/3
3/3 = 1
1 = .999…

Theres lots of ways to find how 1 = .9 repeating

item.dc:creator: @kennyboy93 kennyboy93
item.description:
@kennyboy93 wrote:

[quote=“lothy, post:73, topic:65609”][quote author=kennyboy93 link=topic=95384.msg1015156#msg1015156 date=1173972000]

While you’re playing around with maths, you can argue about this too <3

x^3 = x^2
x^3 - x^2 = 0
x^2(x - 1) = 0

therefore x - 1 = 0 OR x^2 = 0
x = 1 OR x = 0

tries not to sound like a smartarse

First of all, x - 1 = 0 means the same thing as x = 1
Second of all, (x+1)(x-1)(x+10)(x^2-5)(x+3.14159)(x-squareroot(5))=0 would mean:
x = 1,-1,-10,-3.14259,squareroot(5)
and x^2 = 5 (which is the same as x = squareroot(5), i know)
[/quote]
You fale. I had already solved the equation. I merely brought it up to prove the concept that this entire argument is about - that one thing can have two values (0.9repeta = 1, and 1 = 1).[/quote]

It was just the ‘argue about this too’ part that I couldn’t help responding to.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Javacisnotrecognized _^_
item.description:
@Javacisnotrecognized wrote:

I’m surprise at how many of you misunderstand this. It’s just a different notation, that’s the decimal system for you. 0.111111111… is another symbol for 1/9, 0.44444444… is just another symbol for 4/9, 0.63636363… is just another symbol for 7/11, and 0.9999999999… is just another symbol for 1.

Read full topic

Physically .999i = .999i but in theory .999i = 1, why? Because 1/3 = .333i 1/3x3=1, I believe that .999i = 1 but will always disagree until there is proof that an idiot could understand.

item.dc:creator: @Zach1188 Zach1188
item.description:
@Zach1188 wrote:

[quote=“Zach1188, post:30, topic:65609”]0.999 = 0.999

Amazing.[/quote]

wow. thats spam
let me explain again for dumb peeps
[/quote]
No, it was not spam. 0.(9) = 0.(9), period. Calculators round .(9) (because there really is no way of getting a precise amount, unless you literally had an unlimited amount of RAM).

So, since I’m sure you don’t have infinite RAM,
0.(9) = 0.(9), and,
1 = 1

Intense, eh?
[/quote]

Ah, don’t kids just say the darndest things?
[/quote]
Yes, and this entire thread gives an excellent example.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Javacisnotrecognized _^_
item.description:
@Javacisnotrecognized wrote:

Well, think of it like this. .9999999999 … = .9 + .09 + .009 + .009 + etc. And each of those is

(0.9)(1 + 1/10 + 1/10[sup]2[/sup] + 1/10[sup]3[/sup] + 1/10[sup]4[/sup] …)

and, if you extend it to finite numbers, you would write

0.999 = (9)(1/10 + 10[sup]2[/sup] + 1/10[sup]3[/sup])

if you subtracted any number of that kind from 10 times itself, all the last terms would cancel out except 1/10 and the one at the end. it would look like this:

1/(1 - 1/10[sup]n[/sup]);

where n is however many terms were involved. No matter how high the value of n, that sum will always be between 1 and 1 + 2/10[sup]n[/sup], which means when n becomes infinite, the above looks like this:

1/(1 - 0)

which is equal to 1.[br][size=1]Posted on: March 14, 2007, 08:38:53 PM[/size][hr][quote=“Zach1188, post:60, topic:65609”][quote author=bobby link=topic=95384.msg1011336#msg1011336 date=1173866519]

0.999 = 0.999

Amazing.

wow. thats spam
let me explain again for dumb peeps
[/quote]
No, it was not spam. 0.(9) = 0.(9), period. Calculators round .(9) (because there really is no way of getting a precise amount, unless you literally had an unlimited amount of RAM).

So, since I’m sure you don’t have infinite RAM,
0.(9) = 0.(9), and,
1 = 1

Intense, eh?[/quote]

Ah, don’t kids just say the darndest things?

Read full topic
